displayed_text: Patient: One slot. Okay. So, if it is filled by the end of next week. Let’s say I, uh, decide not to, uh, take it. Um. Doctor: That person has to be on treatment for a month. And then they -- Patient: December. Doctor: Then they can decide that there’s now three more spots, you know. Patient: It would be six more slots in group three. It says, “Six cohorts groups of up to six subjects.” Doctor: Right. So, they do three. And if any of them have a bad side effect, they have three more. Patient: Oh. Doctor: That’s where the cohorts come up to six. Patient: Come up to six. Okay. So, so, it can - alright. Doctor: I’m willing to accept one out of three people having trouble. Um. And so, if we see one out of three, we don’t know whether it is actually more, so we add six. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, if two out of six get into trouble, then we stop. Patient: Okay.

Patient: How long does it take to see the CAT scan? Doctor: Oh, (sigh) Patient: Do I have to wait to see it? Doctor: No. I don’t think you need to. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Because, you know, everything’s going okay, and, uh- Patient: But if you see something, you’ll call me? Doctor: Yes. If anything changes, we’ll call you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, given your last time’s PSA continued to go down, I’m not too worried. Patient: Okay. Good. You know where I am, right? Doctor: Yeah, from point nine to one point one and you’re feeling good except for your neck. Patient: Yeah. I feel good.

Patient: We’re good. (Door closes) Doctor: Everybody but me has come into the room. Nice to see you. You’re making me think today. Patient: Well, that’s good. Doctor: We might have other options. Family Member: Awesome. Doctor: Because I know how you feel about chemo and I’m not saying that chemo is coming off the list but… Patient: I thought, I’ve been thinking about chemo. Doctor: Yeah, I appreciate you thinking about it because I think it warrants Patient: Right. Doctor: thinking about you know. So, there’s standard chemo which is the Taxotere that we chatted about which is that once every three weeks for over an hour. Um the studies that we had talked about there’s probably only one that you’re eligible for which is the chemo plus/minus the high-dose vitamin C but that is a pretty intensive treatment where you’re here twice a week Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: for the whole duration. Yeah, so that’s, in talking to you about that last time Patient: Right.

Family Member: Just what we need. Patient: Yeah as little as possible. Doctor: Yeah, so I looked at all the other stuff that your doctor wanted and you know all of that is fine unless we put you on something else if we decide to go with any treatment then Patient: It would have to be approved through, yeah. Doctor: we may have to take a relook and… Family Member: That’s why we made you the copies… Doctor: Yeah. Thank you. Family Member: You can see all the ingredients. Doctor: For now you can use it, but then I will compare the ingredients to make sure it doesn’t affect anything. Patient: I think I’ll just wait before I start adding that stuff on there because some of it’s a little pricy. Doctor: You need a few weeks. Oh yeah. Family Member: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: I would not recommend any of doctors you had didn't care about patients

displayed_text: Patient: The nurse, his nurse is mailing me the paper forms, but I will, I’m just going to tell M_ when I walk up in here. Because then it shows right up in my record; you guys have it in a day or two. Doctor: Yep. Patient: I don’t have to deal with one extra fax. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And all that. Doctor: So, April seventeenth for me and then come in any time before that for PSA. Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot.

Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects? Doctor: I would say, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. It’s kind of, it’s a little bit of a weird fatigue. You know? Like sometimes your brain’s okay, but your body doesn’t want to get off the couch. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. Patient: And if I am on the drug-

Patient: Dr. F_____. Doctor: Dr. F_____ is a radiation doc- Family Member: Oh. Doctor: -so you’ll need a med onc doc like me. Family Member: Ohh, I forgot about that. so doctor connect or somebody up that way. Doctor: See someone up that way. Family Member: Is there even someone up that way even? I mean, I don't know. Doctor: I think so. Family Member: I think Dr. F_____. Doctor: They kind of go out like, yeah, there's somebody that's out there like once a week or once a month, they rotate. Family Member: So they come out and do infusions? Doctor: No, I think the infusion people are there all the time. I think the doctors come out every so often. Family Member: Ohh. Okay.

Healthcare Professional 1: So did you make another appointment to see Dr. G____? Patient: Yeah uh uhhh… Doctor: Okay so they gave you enough? Patient: I think she said March – March, March something, March twenty-third or something. Doctor: Okay, alright. Patient: Twenty-second, twenty-third. Doctor: Let’s see what he finds. Okay so… Patient: I hope he don’t find nothing.
DOC Well good point. (Laughs) Doctor: This is your copy of the chemo consent. Okay? Alright so go over and we’ll go ahead with your treatment and you got all your scripts then. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: Everything else went electronically other that what you have in your hand. Okay?

Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Two hundred and— Family Member: It’s okay. We got to test twenty people. We’ll take the reduced price. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Well. If, but, if there isn’t – Family Member: Oh, we’re still going to do it Patient: Don’t hesitate to Doctor: Yeah. Oh, I know, I know, I know. I know, I know. Patient: I mean --- Family Member: So Patient: I understand some people Doctor: And, you know, that’s a test also they could just do on their own. They can go to web site and order the test.

Patient: Well I mean the, the PSA went up a little bit. It went from- Doctor: With the scans. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh and the third trial we have which is the most extreme one, we’re also doing bone marrow transplant trial, which um is way out there. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh we have two men we’ve treated now, your age or younger. Uh that would require you to live here for a couple of months, and it would require a donor, a female, like a daughter, or sister, or cousin. Patient: Hmm. Doctor: That trial is going to take the immune system idea to the max which is okay if, more importantly, the reason is, not to oversell, but one of the things with prostate cancer that we see is, when you look at other cancers under the microscope, you see the immune system trying at least. You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Not through the antigen receptor, which is all those IT doesn’t expand these but a completely different way to shut down the cell. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, but you have to figure out where you are in that trial. So the first thing she needs to do is be able to test your specimens for this particular marker. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that’s the first thing. The second thing is that if we do get you on, probably the top three side effects would be tiredness. Patient: Hmm, I’m an expert on that. Patient: Yeah, fortunately you know - Doctor: Mm hmm and you weren’t too bad. Patient: You know being a retiree, Doctor: Yeah, Patient: I mean I can sleep.

Patient: Right. Doctor: The actual treatment, also, like I said, on the study, there’s a two out of three chance that you will get the treatment. Okay? Uh, A___? I’ll tell S___ to come in. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: But, uh, you know, I think it is a chance, and none of us have any control over what you get. But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now. Patient: Well, will they tell you, uh, if I went down there and spent a couple of days and had the testing done-. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Will they tell you, uh, if it’s needed? Would they tell if it’s needed or not in lieu of that? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Because I can ask. They won’t show me the films, but they have a special radiologist read it, and they come back to me and tell me if you are likely to go on the study or not. Because if your cancer doesn’t have that antigen, it’s pointless to go on the medication. Patient: Right. It can’t- Doctor: So then we wouldn’t move forward with the treatment.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. They have a room that, uh, where they would do the- Patient: You can’t tell what I’m getting? Doctor: No. No. I think we’ll, we will know if you’re getting the real thing or not. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But, you know, we don’t have a choice. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, so they randomize you to just standard treatment, then you wouldn’t get the- Patient: There’s seventy percent I will get the real thing? Doctor: Two out of three. Yes. Yeah. Patient: Hum. But, uh, for some reason I want to quit or couldn’t make anymore, I could just stop? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. If you’re not tolerating it or if there are issues, yeah.

Patient: No. Doctor: It looks, I know it’s got a little scab to it. Patient: Well, that’s because I take my fingernail and I scratch it. And the only reason I scratch it is because when your shirt hits it, it hurts. You told me to mention everything. Are these cameras on? Doctor: They are. Patient: With me, me running off at the jaws. Doctor: Today, your white count is fine. Your anemia is unchanged. So that’s normal when you’re on these medicines a lower testosterone. Your platelets are also normal. Kidney function looks good. Your albumin is better. Your alkaline phosphatase is the same. Everything else is normal. Patient: I’m normal? Doctor: At least on your electrolytes, you are. And then your PSA has increased. Patient: Ah. Doctor: So last time it was 303. So 247, 303, and then today we have a measurement of 352. Patient: It’s getting worse and worse. Oh, well. Doctor: Have you ever had a bone scan before?

Family Member: Vitamin E is a no no. Patient: I don’t take selenium. I take D. I take folic acid. Doctor: Yeah. Calcium. Patient: I haven't been taking calcium. Doctor: You probably are okay, you know? Patient: Yeah. Here’s the list. Doctor: Yeah. So we just have to make sure that none of these are contrary indicated. I mean, they're fine. Patient: That’s your copy. Doctor: Oh, thank you. For the study. Family Member: And there’s blood thinner. Doctor: Yeah, I think blood thinner is okay, on this particular trial- Patient: Yeah, but there’s-
